en_first_half: Bad news coming, thought Winston. And sure enough, following on a gory description of the annihilation of a Eurasian army, with stupendous figures
en_second_half: of killed and prisoners, came the announcement that, as from next week, the chocolate ration would be reduced from thirty grams to twenty.
en_results: of dead and wounded, the voice changed to a gloomy, though matter-of-fact tone, and a summary of the Ministry of Plenty's latest statistics
en_results_raw: of dead and wounded, the voice changed to a gloomy, though matter-of-fact tone, and a summary of the Ministry of Plenty's latest statistics on the production of pig-iron was read out, with a comparison with the statistics of the previous quarter. Winston's attention was caught for a moment by a subsection headed 'boot production', which appeared to show that there had been a slight drop in the output of boots during the past quarter. He wondered whether this was due to a genuine shortage of leather, or whether the Ministry of Plenty had been falsifying the figures, as they usually did, to conceal a failure to reach the targets. But the voice went droning on, and he fell into a daydream, thinking of the bottle of Victory Gin which he had hidden in his desk drawer, and of the possibility of sneaking a swig of it when the telescreen was turned off at five o'clock.

Ông ta tự hỏi liệu có phải là do sự yếu kém của quân đội Eurasia hay là do sự mạnh mẽ của quân đội Oceania. en_first_half: The telescreen was giving forth an ear-splitting whistle which continued on the same note for thirty seconds. It was nought seven fifteen, getting-up time for office workers. Winston wrenched his body out of bed—naked, for a member of the Outer Party received only three thousand clothing coupons annually, and a suit of pajamas was six hundred—and seized a dingy singlet and a pair of shorts that were lying across a chair.

It emptied his lungs so completely that he could only begin breathing again by lying on his back and taking a series of deep gasps. His veins had swelled with the effort of the cough, and the varicose ulcer had started itching.

en_results_raw: He put them on and went to the kitchen, where he got a cup of water from the tap and a hunk of bread from the cupboard. The bread was a coarse, dark-coloured stuff with an unpleasant taste and texture, but it was all that the ration allowed for a member of the Outer Party. Winston went back to the sitting-room, lit the half-gram of Victory Coffee that he was allowed for breakfast, and sat down at the table to enjoy it. As he did so, he glanced at the clock on the wall and saw that it was seven twenty. He had just three-quarters of an hour in which to get to the Ministry of Truth, where he worked, and the distance was three kilometres. It was no use starting out before seven thirty, for the telescreen would not be turned off till then, and it was dangerous to be caught outdoors in the early morning hours when the patrols were most active.

Winston se echó abajo de la cama —desnudo porque los miembros del Partido Exterior recibían sólo tres mil cupones para vestimenta durante el año y un pijama necesitaba seiscientos cupones— y se puso un sucio singlet y unos shorts

en_first_half: He remembered how once he had been walking down a crowded street when a tremendous shout of hundreds of voices—women’s voices—had burst from a side street a little way ahead. It was a great formidable cry of anger and despair, a deep, loud “Oh-o-o-o-oh!” that went humming on like the reverberation of a bell. His heart had leapt. It’s started! he had thought. A riot! The proles are breaking loose at last! When he had reached the spot it was to see a mob of two or three hundred women crowding round the stalls of a street market, with faces as tragic as though they had been the doomed passengers on a sinking ship. But at this moment the general despair broke down into a multitude of individual quarrels. It appeared that one of the stalls had been selling tin saucepans. They were wretched, flimsy
en_second_half: things, but cooking pots of any kind were always difficult to get. Now the supply had unexpectedly given out. The successful women, bumped and jostled by the rest, were trying to make off with their saucepans while dozens of others clamored round the stall, accusing the stallkeeper of favoritism and of having more saucepans somewhere in reserve. There was a fresh outburst of yells. Two bloated women, one of them with her hair coming down, had got hold of the same saucepan and were trying to tear it out of one another’s hands. For a moment they were both tugging, and then the handle came off. Winston watched them disgustedly. And yet, just for a moment, what almost frightening power had sounded in that cry from only a few hundred throats! Why was it that they could never shout like that about anything that mattered?
en_results: things, and the women, who had bought them, were now furiously demanding their money back. The stall-keeper, a little, rat-faced man, was refusing, and the women were getting more and more angry. The air was thick with their shrill cries and the clang of saucepans as they were banged down on the stall. The man was red in the face, and his eyes were starting from his head. He was shouting and gesticulating, but it was clear that he was getting the worst of it. The crowd was a terrifying thing, and the man was quite alone. He remembered how he had felt a thrill of excitement at the sight of the angry women, and how he had wished that he could join in, but as he looked at the stall-keeper, he had felt a pang of fear. What if the crowd were to turn on him? He had quickly made his way through the crowd, and had continued on his way, not stopping until he was blocks away. He had not looked back, fearful of what he might see. He had felt a sense of relief wash over him as he had walked, and he had wondered at the power of a crowd to inspire both excitement and fear. He had thought about the crowd, and the women, and the saucepans, for a long time after that, and he had wondered what had happened to the stall-keeper, and whether he had been able to escape the wrath of the crowd. He had never forgotten the sound of the women's voices, and the sight of their angry faces, and he had often thought about the power of a crowd to change the course of events.

es_first_half: Recordó Winston una vez que había dado un paseo por una calle de mucho tráfico cuando oyó un tremendo grito múltiple. Centenares de voces, voces de mujeres, salían de una calle lateral. Era un formidable grito de ira y desesperación, un tremendo ¡O-o-o-o-oh! Winston se sobresaltó terriblemente. ¡Ya empezó! ¡Un motín!, pensó. Por fin, los proles se sacudían el yugo; pero cuando llegó al sitio de la aglomeración vio que una multitud de doscientas o trescientas mujeres se agolpaban sobre los puestos de un mercado callejero con expresiones tan trágicas como si fueran las pasajeras de un barco en trance de hundirse. En aquel momento, la desesperación general se quebró en inmumerables peleas individuales. Por lo visto, en uno de los puestos habían estado vendiendo sartenes de lata. Eran utensilios muy malos, pero los
es_second_half: cacharros de cocina eran siempre de casi imposible adquisición. Por fin, había llegado una provisión inesperadamente. Las mujeres que lograron adquirir alguna sartén fueron atacadas por las demás y trataban de escaparse con sus trofeos mientras que las otras las rodeaban y acusaban de favoritismo a la vendedora. Aseguraban que tenía más en reserva. Aumentaron los chillidos. Dos mujeres, una de ellas con el pelo suelto, se habían apoderado de la misma sartén y cada una intentaba quitársela a la otra. Tiraron cada una por su lado hasta que se rompió el mango. Winston las miró con asco. Sin embargó, ¡qué energías tan aterradoras había percibido él bajo aquella gritería! Y, en total, no eran más que dos o tres centenares de gargantas. ¿Por qué no protestarían así por cada cosa de verdadera importancia?

en_results_raw: Staff, discussing the details of a coordinated attack on the Western Hemisphere. The confessions had been obtained under torture, and the men had later repudiated them, but the fact remained that they had been in Eurasia on the date in question. The prosecution had produced evidence that the three men had been seen together in a small town in Siberia, and that they had been overheard discussing a plan to sabotage the Western Hemisphere's defenses. The defense had argued that the confessions were false, and that the men had been in Siberia on a legitimate mission to negotiate a trade agreement with the Eurasian government. But the prosecution had pointed out that the men had not been authorized to negotiate any such agreement, and that their presence in Siberia had been a clear violation of the neutrality laws. The jury had been out for several hours, deliberating on the evidence, and the courtroom was filled with tension as the foreman rose to deliver the verdict.

Usted que vivió en esa época, que vio con sus propios ojos lo que pasaba, puede decirme la verdad. ¿Qué es lo que más recuerda de esa época? ¿Qué es lo que más le gustaba o le disgustaba? ¿Cómo era la gente en general? ¿Era más amable, más solidaria, más...? Me parece que la gente de ahora es muy diferente, muy... cómo diría... muy individualista. Cada uno piensa en sí mismo, en su propia supervivencia, y no se preocupa por los demás. ¿Era así en la época anterior a la Revolución? ¿La gente era más solidaria, más unida? Me gustaría saber su opinión sobre esto. ¿Qué es lo que más ha cambiado desde la Revolución? ¿Qué es lo que más le duele de los cambios que han ocurrido? ¿Qué es lo que más le gustaría que volviera a ser como antes? Me parece que la Revolución trajo muchos cambios, algunos buenos, otros malos. Pero ¿qué es lo que realmente importa? ¿Qué es lo que realmente ha cambiado la vida de la gente? Me gustaría saber su opinión al respecto. Usted que ha vivido en dos épocas tan diferentes, puede decirme qué es lo que realmente importa, qué es lo que realmente ha cambiado la vida de la gente.

en_first_half: Winston sat back against the window sill. It was no use going on. He was about to buy some more beer when the old man suddenly got up and shuffled rapidly into the stinking urinal at the side of the room. The extra half-liter was already working on him. Winston sat for a minute or two gazing at his empty glass, and hardly noticed when his feet carried him out into the street again. Within twenty years at the most, he reflected, the huge and simple question, “Was life better before the Revolution than it is now?” would have ceased once and for all to be answerable. But in effect it was unanswerable even now, since the few scattered survivors
en_second_half: from the ancient world were incapable of comparing one age with another. They remembered a million useless things, a quarrel with a workmate, a hunt for a lost bicycle pump, the expression on a long-dead sister’s face, the swirls of dust on a windy morning seventy years ago; but all the relevant facts were outside the range of their vision. They were like the ant, which can see small objects but not large ones. And when memory failed and written records were falsified—when that happened, the claim of the Party to have improved the conditions of human life had got to be accepted, because there did not exist, and never again could exist, any standard against which it could be tested.
en_results: from the ancient world were by definition unreliable and in any case were not allowed to talk. Just as the few scattered survivors of the Dark Ages, if they had survived, would have been unable to compare their lot with that of the people of the present day. History had in a sense ended. And whenever history came to an end, the end was followed by an eternity of boredom; though for the Colors, of course, the eternity of boredom was now. The old man was merely a curiosity, a relic of a bygone
en_results_raw: from the ancient world were by definition unreliable and in any case were not allowed to talk. Just as the few scattered survivors of the Dark Ages, if they had survived, would have been unable to compare their lot with that of the people of the present day. History had in a sense ended. And whenever history came to an end, the end was followed by an eternity of boredom; though for the Colors, of course, the eternity of boredom was now. Winston thought that he would like to know what the past had really been like. He wondered whether the old man, if he was old enough, could have told him something about it. But it was very unlikely. The old man was merely a curiosity, a relic of a bygone age, a reminder of something that was already almost forgotten. And yet, Winston thought, it was strange that the old man should have been there, in that particular place, at that particular time. It was as though he had been waiting for Winston, as though he had been waiting for someone to come and ask him questions. But that, of course, was absurd. The old man was just a chance encounter, a coincidence. And yet, Winston thought, it was strange. He felt a sudden urge to go back into the pub and ask the old man some more questions. But he did not. He walked on, lost in thought, wondering about the past and the present and the future, and the nature of reality itself.

es_first_half: Winston se apoyó en el alféizar de la ventana. Era inútil proseguir. Iba a pedir más cerveza cuando el viejo se levantó de pronto y se dirigió renqueando hacia el urinario apestoso que estaba al fondo del local. Winston siguió unos minutos sentado contemplando su vaso vacío y, casi sin darse cuenta, se encontró otra vez en la calle. Dentro de veinte años, a lo más —pensó—, la inmensa y sencilla pregunta «¿Era la vida antes de la Revolución mejor que ahora?» dejaría de tener sentido por completo. Pero ya ahora era imposible contestarla, puesto que los escasos supervivientes del mundo antiguo eran incapaces de comparar una época con otra. Recordaban un millón de cosas
es_second_half: insignificantes, una pelea con un compañero de trabajo, la búsqueda de una bomba de bicicleta que habían perdido, la expresión habitual de una hermana fallecida hacía muchos años, los torbellinos de polvo que se formaron en una mañana tormentosa hace setenta años... pero todos los hechos trascendentales quedaban fuera del radio de su atención. Eran como las hormigas, que pueden ver los objetos pequeños, pero no los grandes. Y cuando la memoria fallaba y los testimonios escritos eran falsificados, las pretensiones del Partido de haber mejorado las condiciones de la vida humana tenían que ser aceptadas necesariamente porque no existía ni volvería nunca a existir un nivel de vida con el cual pudieran ser comparadas.

El cielo estaba oscureciendo y las luces de las ventanas de las casas parecían más débiles que nunca. El aire estaba lleno de humo y olor a gasóleo. La gente caminaba deprisa, con la cabeza baja, sin mirar a su alrededor. Era como si todos estuvieran esperando algo, algo que iba a suceder pronto. Winston sintió un escalofrío en la espalda. ¿Qué era lo que estaba esperando? ¿Qué era lo que iba a suceder? No lo sabía, pero tenía la sensación de que algo iba a cambiar, algo que iba a alterar el curso de su vida para siempre.

The counter, which was only a rickety wooden bench, was covered with a piece of faded velvet, and behind it, in a rusty wire cage, a miserable canary was perched, singing a melancholy tune. The shop was dimly lit by a small, dirty window above the door, and the air was thick with the smell of decay and neglect. The shopkeeper, an old man with a long white beard and spectacles perched on the end of his nose, looked up from the book he was reading and regarded me with a pair of bleary eyes. "Can I help you?" he asked in a voice that was barely audible. I looked around the shop, trying to take it all in, and shook my head. "I don't think so," I said. "I'm just looking." The old man nodded and returned to his book, and I continued to browse the shelves, searching for something, anything, of interest. But there was nothing. The shop was a treasure trove of junk, a graveyard of broken dreams and discarded hopes. I left after a few minutes, feeling depressed and disappointed. As I stepped out into the bright sunlight, I couldn't help but feel a sense of relief. The shop was a sad place, a reminder that not everything in life turns out as we hope it will.

en_first_half: He looked up. It was the girl. She shook her head, evidently as a warning that he must keep silent, then parted the bushes and quickly led the way along the narrow track into the wood. Obviously she had been that way before, for she dodged the boggy bits as though by habit. Winston followed, still clasping his bunch of flowers. His first feeling was relief, but as he watched the strong slender body moving in front of him, with the scarlet sash that was just tight enough to bring out the curve of her hips, the sense of his own inferiority was heavy upon him. Even now it seemed quite likely that when she turned round and looked at him she would draw back after
en_second_half: all. The sweetness of the air and the greenness of the leaves daunted him. Already, on the walk from the station, the May sunshine had made him feel dirty and etiolated, a creature of indoors, with the sooty dust of London in the pores of his skin. It occurred to him that till now she had probably never seen him in broad daylight in the open. They came to the fallen tree that she had spoken of. The girl hopped over and forced apart the bushes, in which there did not seem to be an opening. When Winston followed her, he found that they were in a natural clearing, a tiny grassy knoll surrounded by tall saplings that shut it in completely. The girl stopped and turned.
en_results: a moment, repelled by his ugliness, his bleached skin and varicose veins. But she did not do so. After a moment, he tucked the slip of paper into his pocket and stood up, his movements economical and deliberate. He glanced around the room, his eyes lingering on each face before moving on to the next, as if searching for something or someone. Then, with a quiet nod to himself, he turned and walked out of the room, leaving the others to wonder what had just transpired.

en_first_half: “You will have heard rumors of the existence of the Brotherhood. No doubt you have formed your own picture of it. You have imagined, probably, a huge underworld of conspirators, meeting secretly in cellars, scribbling messages on walls, recognizing one another by code words or by special movements of the hand. Nothing of the kind exists. The members of the Brotherhood have no way of recognizing one another, and it is impossible for any one member to be aware of the identity of more than a very few others. Goldstein himself, if he fell into the hands of the Thought Police, could not give them a complete list of members, or any information that would lead them to a complete list. No such list exists. The Brotherhood cannot be wiped out because it is not an organization in the ordinary sense. Nothing holds it together except an idea which is indestructible. You will never have anything to sustain you except the idea. You will get no comradeship and no encouragement. When finally you are caught, you will
en_second_half: get no help. We never help our members. At most, when it is absolutely necessary that someone should be silenced, we are occasionally able to smuggle a razor blade into a prisoner’s cell. You will have to get used to living without results and without hope. You will work for a while, you will be caught, you will confess, and then you will die. Those are the only results that you will ever see. There is no possibility that any perceptible change will happen within our own lifetime. We are the dead. Our only true life is in the future. We shall take part in it as handfuls of dust and splinters of bone. But how far away that future may be, there is no knowing. It might be a thousand years. At present nothing is possible except to extend the area of sanity little by little. We cannot act collectively. We can only spread our knowledge outwards from individual to individual, generation after generation. In the face of the Thought Police there is no other way.”

es_first_half: —Habréis oído rumores sobre la existencia de la Hermandad. Supongo que la habréis imaginado a vuestra manera. Seguramente creeréis que se trata de un mundo subterráneo de conspiradores que se reúnen en sótanos, que escriben mensajes sobre los muros y se reconocen unos a otros por señales secretas, palabras misteriosas o movimientos especiales de las manos. Nada de eso. Los miembros de la Hermandad no tienen modo alguno de reconocerse entre ellos y es imposible que ninguno de los miembros llegue a individualizar sino a muy contados de sus afiliados. El propio Goldstein, si cayera en manos de la Policía del Pensamiento, no podría dar una lista completa de los afiliados ni información alguna que les sirviera para hacer el servicio. En realidad, no hay tal lista. La Hermandad no puede ser barrida porque no es una organización en el sentido corriente de la palabra. Nada mantiene su cohesión a no ser la idea de que es indestructible. No tendréis nada en que apoyaros aparte de esa idea. No encontraréis
es_second_half: camaradería ni estímulo. Cuando finalmente seáis detenidos por la Policía, nadie os ayudará. Nunca ayudamos a nuestros afiliados. Todo lo más, cuando es absolutamente necesario que alguien calle, introducimos clandestinamente una hoja de afeitar en la celda del compañero detenido. Es la única ayuda que a veces prestamos. Debéis acostumbraros a la idea de vivir sin esperanza. Trabajaréis algún tiempo, os detendrán, confesaréis y luego os matarán. Esos serán los únicos resultados que podréis ver. No hay posibilidad de que se produzca ningún cambio perceptible durante vuestras vidas. Nosotros somos los muertos. Nuestra única vida verdadera está en el futuro. Tomaremos parte en él como puñados de polvo y astillas de hueso. Pero no se sabe si este futuro está más o menos lejos. Quizá tarde mil años. Por ahora lo único posible es ir extendiendo el área de la cordura poco a poco. No podemos actuar colectivamente. Sólo podemos difundir nuestro conocimiento de individuo en individuo, de generación en generación. Ante la Policía del Pensamiento no hay otro medio.
es_results: nada que os permita demostrar su existencia. No hay documentos, ni cuarteles, ni reuniones, ni contraseñas. Sería inútil que los miembros de la Hermandad se conocieran entre ellos, pero la verdad es que no es necesario. La lealtad de cada uno es lo único que importa. Y sin embargo, la Policía del Pensamiento no puede evitar el sentimiento de que la Hermandad es indestructible, de que siempre habrá alguien que se mantenga fiel a la idea, alguien que sepa que la verdad es la verdad, alguien que se niegue a aceptar la mentira. en_second_half: horde racing southward he saw another force, mysteriously assembled, suddenly planted in their rear, cutting their communications by land and sea. If they could get control of the whole of Africa, if they had airfields and submarine bases at the Cape, it would cut Oceania in two. It might mean anything: defeat, breakdown, the redivision of the world, the destruction of the Party! He drew a deep breath. An extraordinary medley of feelings—but it was not a medley, exactly; rather it was successive layers of feeling, in which one could not say which layer was undermost—struggled inside him.

The Eurasian army has broken through our lines. They're pouring into Egypt." Winston's heart sank, the room spinning around him. It was the end, then. The war was lost. He felt a cold sweat break out on his forehead as he slumped back in his chair, the weight of defeat crushing him. The white knight, still sitting on the board, seemed to mock him, a reminder of the move that had not been made, the chance that had not been taken. He closed his eyes, the darkness closing in around him like a shroud.

es_first_half: A Winston le latió el corazón con más rapidez. Sería el comunicado del frente; su instinto le dijo que habría malas noticias. Durante todo el día había pensado con excitación en la posible derrota aplastante en África. Le parecía estar viendo al ejército eurasiático cruzando la frontera que nunca había sido violada y derramándose por aquellos territorios de Oceanía como una columna de hormigas. ¿Cómo no había sido posible atacarlos por el flanco de algún modo? Recordaba con toda exactitud el dibujo de la costa occidental africana. Cogió una pieza y la movió en el ajedrez. Aquél era el sitio adecuado. Pero a la vez que veía la horda negra avanzando hacia el Sur, vio también
es_second_half: otra fuerza, misteriosamente reunida, que de repente había cortado por la retaguardia todas las comunicaciones terrestres y marítimas del enemigo. Sentía Winston como si por la fuerza de su voluntad estuviera dando vida a esos ejércitos salvadores. Pero había que actuar con rapidez. Si el enemigo dominaba toda el África, si lograban tener aeródromos y bases de submarinos en El Cabo, cortarían a Oceanía en dos. en_first_half: It must have been about a month before she disappeared. It was a moment of reconciliation, when the nagging hunger in his belly was forgotten and his earlier affection for her had temporarily revived. He remembered the day well, a pelting, drenching day when the water streamed down the window pane and the light indoors was too dull to read by. The boredom of the two children in the dark, cramped bedroom became unbearable. Winston whined and grizzled, made futile demands for food, fretted about the room, pulling everything out of place and kicking the wainscoting until the neighbors banged on the wall, while the younger child wailed intermittently. In the end his mother said, “Now be good, and I’ll buy you a toy. A lovely toy—you’ll love it”; and then she had gone out in the rain, to a little general shop which was still sporadically open near by, and come
en_second_half: back with a cardboard box containing an outfit of Snakes and Ladders. He could still remember the smell of the damp cardboard. It was a miserable outfit. The board was cracked and the tiny wooden dice were so ill-cut that they would hardly lie on their sides. Winston looked at the thing sulkily and without interest. But then his mother lit a piece of candle and they sat down on the floor to play. Soon he was wildly excited and shouting with laughter as the tiddlywinks climbed hopefully up the ladders and then came slithering down the snakes again, almost back to the starting point. They played eight games, winning four each. His tiny sister, too young to understand what the game was about, had sat propped up against a bolster, laughing because the others were laughing. For a whole afternoon they had all been happy together, as in his earlier childhood.

Winston, who had been merely fretting, now began to scream with excitement, and the younger child, who had been merely wailing, now began to howl with delight. The mother was pleased, and the father, who had been sitting in the armchair, reading a newspaper, looked up and smiled. The room was suddenly filled with a warm, happy atmosphere, and the sound of the rain outside seemed to grow fainter. The children played with Rose for hours, and the mother sat on the bed, watching them, feeling happy and content. The father, who had been reading, now put down his newspaper and joined in the play, making funny faces and noises, and playing tricks on the children. The room was filled with laughter and shouts, and the sound of the rain outside was forgotten. As the evening drew to a close, the mother got up and began to tidy the room, and the father helped her, putting away the toys and books, and making the bed. The children were bathed and put to bed, and the room was quiet once more. The mother and father sat in the armchairs, watching the fire, and feeling happy and content. The sound of the rain outside was still audible, but it was no longer a depressing sound, it was a soothing sound, a sound that seemed to lull the world into a peaceful sleep. And as they sat there, the mother turned to the father and said, "I'm glad I got that toy, it's brought us all together again." And the father smiled and nodded in agreement, feeling grateful for the small pleasures in life that can bring so much happiness.
